Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer's decision to award only 5 points for education was reasonable
Evidence_Assessment: Mr. Hameed provided evidence of enrollment at Islamia College, a recognized bachelor’s degree, and confirmation of 14 years of study from the Higher Education Commission
Decision_Outcome: Visa officer awarded only 5 points for education
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant must prove eligibility under IRPA regulations
Credibility_Factor: Officer doubted attendance but did not require proof per regulations
Legal_Rule: Applicants must prove a two-year bachelor’s degree and at least 14 years of full-time or equivalent studies to receive 20 points
Procedural_Issue: Officer did not follow procedural fairness by failing to request additional proof if in doubt
Grounds_for_Claim: Unreasonable denial of education points despite meeting regulatory requirements
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Procedural fairness not upheld as officer did not seek clarification
Key_Evidence_Considered: Bachelor’s degree from Islamia College, confirmation of 14 years of study from Higher Education Commission
Applicant_Challenge: Challenged denial of permanent residence due to insufficient education points
Court_Result: Allowed judicial review, ordered re-evaluation with 20 education points
Defendant_Response: Did not require proof of attendance despite doubts
Outcome: Permanent residence application denied initially, under reconsideration
Remedy_Sought: Award of 20 education points and re-evaluation of application
Legal_Provision: IRPA sections related to skilled worker points assessment
Legal_Provision_Cited: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, Schedule I, factors for assessing human capital
Applicable_Process: Federal Skilled Worker Program points-based assessment
Governing_Rule: Regulatory requirement of two-year degree and 14 years of study for 20 points
